pros: Good pay, good benefits, yearly raises, centrally located by airport. Great support programs and reps to get you in touch with community services you might need. Free (but very limited/discounted) legal services plan. They pay for your health, dental, and vision insurance. FORD employees are given priority for intake at The Brook Hospital. They pay for college tuition, I think it's $6k per year, possibly per semester. The union can fight for you to keep your job in most instances, along with getting your termination reversed in many cases as well, of course, depending on what rules you broke. There is air conditioning in break rooms, restrooms, offices; and working fans at most every work station. There's a medical dept in the plant with nurses and a doctor for work related injuries or illnesses that occur while on the job. They also have a physical therapy dept on site for those who are prescribed pt to try and help minimize damage from repetitive motion injuries. You go to medical/physical therapy during your shift (while still getting paid) as someone covers your job for you to do so. There's fun union activities at the union hall/out in the community for your family. Holiday parties, trunk-or-treat, employee appreciation picnics, etc. If you surround yourself with the right people, you can create a great support system/community/extended family for you and your family.
cons:
Very strange factory "culture". Tons of negativity, gossip, drugs, harassment, favoritism, manipulation, and taking advantage of people. You're best to go to work, not socialize with most, and head home straight after. This isn't all there is of course, but it's overwhelmingly THE culture there. They've only been hiring temps the past few years, not hiring them full-time for years. You only know the max length of your shift, but time varies daily and you don't know what time your shift ends until after halfway through your shift each day. People take advantage (on a whole other level) of any and every loophole they can find, in every single policy resulting in VERY divided and bitter co-workers and regular policy change to try to combat these issues. You have to save your vacation time to use during shut down bc each year. The parking lots are huge and you must get to work very early in order to park, walk through the turnstiles, and inside the building to wherever your specific job may be. There are security guards in the lots but there's still quite a bit of vandalism, theft, and just plain "working hazard" damage done to vehicles by people dropping screws and other things in the parking lots. Lots of flat tires for sure. Open drug/alcohol abuse in parking lots on breaks and in between shifts, so it's a difficult place for many to remain sober (without a very good plan ahead of time.) I imagine most factories of this size all having similar issues, but this is the only one I've worked at so I've got nothing to compare it to other than what I've heard from others. There's no a/c, but there is heat for a couple months in mid winter. It's a very loud environment, and an extremely monotonous and boring job that begins breaking your body down fairly early on with all the repetition. The pay is so high because they understand what you're giving up when you work there. You're ultimately trading your quality of life for a higher paycheck and better benefits, but by the time you make it to retirement your body is going to be hurting so much you won't be able to enjoy things as you would've if you'd worked elsewhere. That being said, you'll have the money to do things you wouldn't have been able to if you'd worked elsewhere. Figure out your priority, health or money; it's definitely a trade-off there. I honestly don't believe there's a way to have both if you work there your entire career. Possibly switching jobs frequently to limit repetitive motion injuries, staying ahead of probable injuries and taking extremely good care of your body, and finding ways to take time off through the year to give your body a much needed break to recuperate are the only ideas I can come up with that might help reach that goal of trying to have both.

review_title: Some Engineering with lots of paperwork
pros:
Lots of resources. TDRM's are great places to learn. Lots of systems of lesson's learned and best practices, but they are not enough to get the whole picture and mistakes still happen.

There are lots of people that are very good at their jobs. There are wonderful people who will help you constantly at WERS, or PDLs, or whatever other archaic/unruly system Ford is currently using.

People are typically easy to talk to and will do their jobs. You can go around and stop by practically anyone's desk and discuss an issue, you will come to an agreement, and path forward. And know, that you'll only have to prod them 3 times to get what they promised you.
cons:
This will completely depend on your group, but mainly your supervisor. 

Your group is your program, NOT your commodity. Ford is completely oriented towards making a vehicle fit together, NOT making each component work the best. This is supposed to cause the different commodities to come together but it rarely does. It also causes repeated mistakes to happen. So you'll see the same issues on multiple programs because the same commodity engineers don't talk with each other that often.

Also, products are moving so quickly, by the time an issue is detected, another program has it already in the pipeline. Issues are caused by lack of communication between the different engineers of the same commodity AND when specs change in one group that cause issues in another.

There are so many supervisors that seem like lost workers. They have no idea what they are doing or how they got into their position. Even though they have a dozen people reporting to them, they will also be releasing parts and are too busy to BE a boss, or especially, a leader. Because of that, you will be on your own. Fend for yourself, most people will not try to help you on your issues. Rarely, yes, someone will, a bit, but that's rare.

So many reporting systems!!! The same 5 pieces of information will need to be reported 90 times a month. Redundant work takes up 2/3 of your engineering time. Management implicitly favors this work rather than making sure everything else is complete.
Advice to Management
Train your supervisors and managers at BEING supervisors and managers. Being a good engineer is the worst qualification! Those people rarely have the people and organizational skills to be a good supervisor.

Force commodity: engineers/finance/buyers/etc to sit together! So many issues can be solved by doing this. If someone changes jobs, then they have to MOVE desks.

pros:
I was an Engineer (electric vehicles related)

Performance reviews are a joke. You copy your generic goals from the start-of-year to the comments section. Supervisors do not even meet to discuss your career or to give any feedback on what you can do better.

Red tape. Every single technical decision goes to layers of supervisors and managers and it never goes to technical experts. I noticed that even the most hard working people spent most of their time getting approvals from managers instead of working with technical experts to make great products.

To make matters worse, middle management does not value people for their technical skills. you can come with a bachelors/masters/phd or spend 10 years working at Ford, there are very few managers who will appreciate you for your skills. Most employees (at GSR level) are considered soldiers in an army; the managers only care about the quantity of soldiers, not who they are or what they bring to the table. Makes it very easy to stay under-radar if you don't like to work. Becomes very hard to do any work if you want to progress in career.

employee_status: Product Development Engineer in Dearborn, MI
review_title: BEWARE-Never give advance notice if you plan to leave
pros: I had a great supervisor and team. They paid my relocation costs when I first started work for them.
cons:
I left Ford when I was recruited into a better job offer, plain and simple. I planned to give 3 weeks notice as a courtesy to my team that I still highly respected so I could help them transition a new team member into my position during a very busy time in the project cycle. Beware, the day you give notice they immediately excuse you from work and cut you off no matter what date you list in your resignation letter. It seems they have a secret walk out policy. Don't bother giving notice until you're ready to leave the same day. I lost thousands and thousands of dollars in retirement money that would have vested in just a week had they honored a 2 weeks notice. I was promised two weeks additional pay and unused vacation in my exit interview and a month later I haven't received anything and have been trying for over two weeks to reach someone and find out what happened. They send you to an e-mail address that only responds every 4-5 days, and knows nothing. The person who gave me the promise never returned any of my calls until my wife called then emailed and referred me to the same phone number that knows nothing, well actually pretends to know nothing as I’ve called them enough now to get the feeling their responses are scripted. They give a pretense of helping me and answering my questions but we are still back at square one after over two weeks and I’ve had to rephrase my question about ten times and they still don’t get it. Ford touts how good they are at communicating but anytime I try to call and get information, no one knows anything (or maybe pretends not to) and I'm just referred to automated e-mail addresses and voicemails. Even as an employee we found out major company news from the mainstream news before they told their employees. Horrible communication. You can't find contact information anywhere to a live voice, probably on purpose. I wanted to leave in a friendly manner but instead they seem to have made false promises and treated me like outsider scum so I've lost all respect I had for them which is really sad. Thanks a lot Ford, it didn't have to be this way. If you plan on staying there the rest of your life then maybe you'll enjoy it if you can handle all the lack of productivity and frustration that might arise when trying to work with union employees and if you don’t mind a bonus that seems to be only a fifth the size of what the union workers get, but if you ever have to make a career change, watch out for the Corporate beast and be sure to make sure all your own interests are in line before you leave. Yes I’m bitter now, I’ve wasted so much time trying to get only what was promised to me and I wasn’t bitter when I walked in to give my notice or even when they walked me out the door although I was shocked. The last month of trying to work with completely clueless and incompetent Ford employees, policies and procedures has ruined it for me, zero customer service, and intentional avoidance. I’d be ashamed to drive a vehicle produced by a company run in such a manner and I can’t believe I worked for such a company, how sad.
Advice to Management
Don't make promises you don't intend to keep. Scrap the walk out policy. I understand you're afraid people will steal company secrets when they leave so you walk them out the door, but all this does is alienate them and harm your reputation in the long run. If they were really going to steal secrets they would have done that before they gave notice unless they are really brainless. Publish your employee handbook and policies online. Make contact information for departments available instead of hiding behind dead-end automated phone systems and e-mail addresses. Give better bonuses to your engineer and product developers, they can't be replaced by robots and it's a slap in the face to them every time they watch news coverage of the big bonuses line workers are getting every Christmas.
